awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Investigating fault geometries and rupture processes in the Nepal Himalaya following the April 25, 2015 Gorkha earthquake
awd_abstract_narration:
Following the April 25, 2015 Gorkha magnitude 7.8 and the May 12, 2015 magnitude 7.3 earthquakes, the largest earthquakes to occur in the central segment of the Himalaya in 80 years, a collaborative team from Oregon State University, U.C. Riverside, Stanford University, and the University of Texas at El Paso deployed an NSF RAPID-funded aftershock array of 45 seismic stations (41 broadband and short-period seismometers, 14 strong motion sensors) across the Main Himalayan Thrust (MHT) fault where the large earthquakes occurred. The array, known as the Nepal Array Measuring Aftershock Seismicity Trailing Earthquake (NAMASTE) remained in place for 11 months, allowing for a unique data set right over the active Himalayan thrust system. In this proposal, this same collaborative team will analyze the newly collected data set specifically to study the geometry of faults, including the MHT fault, the composition of the crust and upper mantle in the region, the rupture process of this earthquake sequence, and the broader geotectonic setting in the Himalaya and southern Tibet. Collaboration and cooperation between U.S. and Nepalese seismologists is essential to this project, thereby contributing to improvements of Nepalese scientific infrastructure.

The newly collected, high quality NAMASTE array data will allow for a better understanding of the tectonic setting and rupture process of these large earthquakes and will both illuminate the processes causing large Himalayan earthquakes as well as large subduction zone earthquakes. Specifically, we will analyze the NAMASTE array data to address: 1) The geometry of the MHT fault zone, 2) the crustal composition in the MHT region, 3) the fault dynamics from aftershock characterization, and 4) the broader geotectonic setting. To address the geometry of the MHT, we will perform precise aftershock locations, develop a robust seismicity catalog from the NAMASTE and other regional arrays, and perform source characterization of aftershocks that will provide meaningful insights into the fault geometry, slip dynamics, source properties, and evolving state of stress during the aftershock sequence.  To determine crustal composition, we will use local earthquake tomography and ambient noise tomography to derive crustal velocities and use known relationships between velocity and crustal composition and assess the presence and role of fluids in the crust, especially in the regions of active faulting. For fault dynamics, we will examine the spatiotemporal distribution of aftershocks and relation with rupture patches obtained by backprojection to allow for a better understanding of the rupture process and stress changes that occurred during the main shock and aftershocks. Finally, we will explore the broader geotectonic setting of the region by combining NAMASTE array data with other regional stations to derive tomographic velocity models, crustal and upper mantle anisotropy, and Moho and possibly lithospheric depths from receiver functions. We will further compare our seismology datasets with other geophysical and geological datasets (e.g., magnetotellurics, gravity, surface mapping, deformation) to derive the best possible understanding to date of the tectonics of the Himalaya and southern Tibet in Nepal and the surrounding countries.

por.por_cntn:
Himalaya is one of the most emphatic geologic feature on the face of planet earth; it is also one of the most seismically hazardous places with dense population centers like, Kathmandu (Nepal) and Delhi (India). This study aims to develop a better understanding of the physical processes that control the earthquake cycle, tectonics, and future seismic hazard in the Himalayas, particularly in Nepal. These partly depend on our understanding of the plate boundary fault, known as the Main Himalayan Thrust. This is the major fault responsible for large damaging earthquakes along the arc, accommodating subduction of Indian tectonic plate under Eurasia giving rise to this rugged mountain chain. An important task in this regard is to decipher the geometry of the Main Himalayan Thrust as earthquake generation, propagation and arrest all are partly controlled by the fault geometry. A canonical model suggest a simple flat-ramp-flat geometry of the fault – two sub-horizontal planes connected by a gently dipping one. This simple model, however, cannot explain a number of critical observations and characteristics in this area.

In this study, we use a unique seismic dataset collected right after a magnitude 7.8 damaging earthquake in 2015 under Kathmandu, the capital of Nepal. This data came from a dense temporary seismic network we have established immediately after the deadly earthquake. We carefully analyze this rich dataset and produce a high resolution aftershock catalog containing thousands of smaller events that occur after the mainshock. Aftershock time period is characterized by much higher seismic activity relative to the background as aftershocks continue for many years in the area of the mainshock rupture.

We use this catalog to investigate the fault geometry of the Main Himalayan Thrust. Based on our analyses, we found that the geometry of the Main Himalayan Thrust is far more complex than previously thought. It is characterized by two sub-horizontal planes connected by a duplex structure. This is a critical discovery because this duplex structure significantly modify the stress patterns along the fault affecting earthquake patterns produced by the fault. It may have also influenced the rupture propagation of the damaging mainshock. In addition, we found that there is significant lateral variations of earthquake patterns in the aftershock area. It appears that the duplex structure is responsible for producing majority of the aftershocks resulting the lateral variations in the aftershock patterns. Moment tensor and focal mechanisms – other important source parameters of earthquakes – are also consistent with the interpretation of duplex structure. Hence, we update and refine the geometry and structural details of the Main Himalayan Thrust in a significant way that may have critical implications on the earthquake cycle in the Himalayas and related hazards.

This project is a result of international collaboration between scientists in US and Nepal. It provides training to our collogues in Nepal to more effectively analyze seismic data and deal with earthquake hazards. It helps a young scientist (the principal investigator) to develop as a more matured and experienced one. Multiple students in US and Nepal have gained critical hands-on training and experience in cutting-edge seismic research. This study is a major part of a PhD thesis of a graduate student from a minority community.
